text: hi everyone I'm Rachel Arnett I'm a
doctoral student here at HDS
and today I'm excited to share my work
with you about expressing minorities
willingness to express their cultural
identities at work while I'm focusing on
expression of cultural identities will
also be referencing personal I did an
expression which is more related to
gender as well so I just want to quickly
give you a synopsis of some related work
that I'm doing that I'm building on so
this previous work investigates this
notion in literature that cultural
identity expression by a minority is
often assumed to result in less
inclusive behaviors by majority group
members which is typically white
Americans and so we have this intuition
I want to investigate whether this was
the case and what I found was that
actually when minorities talk about
their cultural backgrounds in a rich and
meaningful way sharing thoughts and
emotions about their cultural
backgrounds it actually if anything
results in more inclusive behaviors by
majority group members both socially and
professionally so more likely to be
invited to lunch more likely to be
invited to the important business
meeting for example
I wanted to investigate whether
minorities have an intuition that this
would be the case or whether in fact
minorities will assume that cultural
idea expression leads to less inclusive
behaviors and as a result will make them
less willing to express their cultural
backgrounds and so I ran a study in
which I had minorities just abstractly
think about expressing their cultural
identities to white co-workers and they
imagined expressing either they're
talking about their work or expressing
their personal life or expressing their
cultural background and then there were
asked how they expected their white
co-workers to respond and what I found
is that compared to when minorities
imagined expressing their their work
they actually expected to be more
included when they talked about their
personal lives but less included when
they talked about their cultural
backgrounds so they expected a penalty
there when it came to professional
inclusion compared to when minorities
imagined discussing work they expected
to be less professional included when
they talked about either their personal
lives or their cultural backgrounds but
this cultural penalty was expected to be
the greatest and when looked at looking
at their willingness express their
cultural backgrounds and personalize
they were less willing to
talk about personal lives compared to
work and even less likely to wanted to
discuss their cultural backgrounds and
so at first this seems like it confirms
this notion in the literature that
minorities are hesitant to talk about
their cultural backgrounds due to
penalties from their majority group
co-workers but I wanted to investigate
this further because sometimes what we
think about in the abstract is a little
bit different from what we find when we
think about concrete scenarios and so I
ran another study in which I had
minorities think about talking about
different topics to a specific white
co-worker so they depending on condition
work experimental condition were told to
imagine discussing a work topic
something about their personal
background focusing on rich or more
intimate details about their personal
life something rich and intimate about
their cultural background or something
surface level about their cultural
background and in all these cases they
actually had to write about a specific
you know scenario or activity that they
participated and imagine sharing it to
that specific co-worker and they had to
write out what that co-workers responds
with be so it's really concretely going
to the thought exercise and so what I
found was that compared to when
minorities imagined discussing their
work they once again expected to be more
socially included when they talked about
their personal lives but in contrast to
the previous study they expected to also
be more socially included when I talked
about their cultural backgrounds as well
whether it was rich or surface-level
when I looked at expectation regarding
professional inclusion compared to
discussing work they expected no
differences in how how much they would
be professional included if they talked
about their personal life or their
cultural backgrounds and when looking at
their willingness to express these
different aspects of themselves they
were just as willing to talk about their
personal lives as they were about their
cultural backgrounds and so I think what
this work suggests is that generally
speaking talking about aspects of our
personal lives or our cultural
backgrounds can be scary it can be
intimidating but and many times with in
many contexts and with many people this
actually might be the case right those
might be justified feelings however I
think it's at least worthwhile to
consider whether or not you've reached
this conclusion by thinking about things
in the abstract and if so I think it's
worthwhile to engage in the thought
exercise of concretely
during how a specific co-worker might
respond to these types of expressions
and perhaps we might find ourselves
feeling empowered to be more authentic
in the workplace when you pair this with
my other work that I shared a little bit
of at the beginning I think it does
actually suggest that the minorities can
actually do this add to a greater degree
and actually gain a greater sense of
inclusion thank you
